September 1918.SECRET.NAVAL WEEKLY APPRECIATION-No. 71.i - i ^ \ a- \\Week ended 28th September, 1918.NAVAL OPERATIONS. Minelaying has been carried out in the North Sea and Heligoland Bight. North Sea.On 28th September our monitors carried out a bombardment of German coast defences Handera . on the Belgian coast. Aircraft co-operated, and spotted successfully, two direct hits Area-on the battery at Sylte being signalled.In addition to co-operatirig with our Naval Forces in the bombardment of the Belgian coast, R.A.F. machines from Dunkirk have assisted the Belgian Army in their attacks, with bombs and machine gun fire, over 13 tons of bombs having been dropped on 28th September alone. The railway junction at Oortemarck and Thourout were heavily bombed and many direct hits were made on horse transport and bodies of troops. In the course of the operations four enemy machines were destroyed and four driven down out of control. Thirteen of our machines are missing, seven of which failed to return from the enerriy's lines after a sudden and violent rain storm in the early hours of the morning. .Machines from Dunkirk have also carried out the following raids : Approximate weight ofDate. Ten of our machines are missing.On 21st September nine machines from Otranto carried out a raid on the Austrian Mediter-Headquarters Camp at Ragozimi in Albania, a ton of bombs being dropped. Direct ranean. hits were observed on railway entrenchments and buildings as well as on the camp.During a reconnaissance over Kavaja Rashtbul and the new aerodrome at Durazzo, one of our machines had to land 3,000 yards inside the enemy lines, and the pilot and observer were taken prisoners. Endeavours were made by the Italians to destroy the machine by artillery fire, but with what result is not known. The other machines returned safely.On 24th September three enemy machines attacked Mudros and destroyed the sea-plane station at Talikna, including three hangars, ten seaplanes, a repair shop and a quantity of stores. There were no casualties. Bombs were also dropped in Mudros East, killing one native and wounding 2 others. Steps were immediately taken to replace the seaplanes, plant, &c.(C1428) Wt. - 50 10/18 B * S A 2ATTACK UPON ENEMY SUBMARINES.Submarines During the week under review, from 24 to 26 large enemy submarines of a type which-operating. 0perates further afield than the North Sea, were located. No enemy ships have entered or left Rotterdam. FOREIGN NAVAL INTELLIGENCE.Russia.The flotilla operating on the Northern Dvina has made considerable progress and has inflicted great losses on the enemy. Several mines have been met with, and the advance is temporarily delayed while sweeping is in progress.It having been reported that bombs had been placed on board four different steamers before their departure from Archangel, General Poole has taken steps to have guards placed on all ships in that port. Tie labour situation at Archangel is very complex and strikes are of daily occurrence..An unconfirmed report states that Colonel Duroff has been nominated as Governor-General of Archangel, where he will be subservient only to the Central Government at Samara. Admiral Ivanoff, Russian Senior Naval Officer at Archangel, has been dismissed without reason by the Government.No more United States troops will be sent to Northern Russian ports.As a result of the recent Karelian victory at Ukhta, considerable numbers of new recruits have been enrolled for service.A Russian W/T message of 24th September states that owing to the occupation of Krasnovodsk, Fort Alexandrovsk and Petrovsk by the British, and of Baku by the Turks, any naval expedition on the Caspian is postponed.Commodore Norris reports that the Caspian Fleet is disorganised and under the absolute control of Bicharakov, who would consider any attempt at bribery or purchase as a sign of weakness. The Commodore proposes to ignore the fleet so long as it remains inactive, and meanwhile will press on with the arming of steamers under his control. Of these he has about 37 at Enzeli and 2 at Krasnovodsk, while he reports the presence of 11 at Baku and of 17 at Petrovsk.Naval Staff.3rd October, 1918.
